Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story:
The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my taxi crawling along the icy road. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his flight. “Please, can’t you go any faster?” he pleaded, desperation in his voice. I wanted to reassure him, to fulfill my duty as a driver and get him to the airport safely and on time, but the roads were treacherous, and every instinct told me to be cautious.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from the convent: the sisters were gathering for a special healing service for Sister Agnes, who had taken a sudden turn for the worse. It was outside our usual schedule, but my presence was expected—no, needed. I could almost hear Mother Superior’s gentle voice reminding me of my vows, the importance of community, of prayer.

My heart pounded as I weighed the urgency of my passenger’s journey against the call of my faith and my sisters. The storm outside was nothing compared to the turmoil inside me, torn between the road ahead and the sanctuary I longed to reach.
